description:
Artemia franciscana, commonly known as the California brine shrimp or San Francisco brine shrimp, is a species of small aquatic crustacean that belongs to the genus Artemia. It is a member of the family Artemiidae and is found in saline lakes, inland seas, and other hypersaline water bodies in various parts of the world, particularly in the western United States and Mexico.

Artemia franciscana is a small, elongated, and transparent shrimp-like organism, typically measuring between 8 to 17 millimeters in length. It has a segmented body, compound eyes, and a pair of antennae. The species is known for its ability to thrive in highly saline environments, where it can tolerate salt concentrations up to 25% and temperatures ranging from 6°C to 35°C.

One of the unique features of Artemia franciscana is its ability to produce cysts, or dormant eggs, that can withstand harsh environmental conditions and remain viable for long periods. These cysts can hatch when environmental conditions become favorable, allowing the species to survive and reproduce in challenging environments.

Artemia franciscana plays an important role in the food chain of saline ecosystems, serving as a food source for various aquatic organisms, including fish, birds, and other invertebrates. It is also widely used in aquaculture and the aquarium industry as a live food source for the larvae and juveniles of many fish and invertebrate species.
